VOL XXIX, No 37
HOPKINS LACROSSE MEN
TO MEET ONONDAGA
INDIANS
Red:nen from North Will Test Black
and Blue Stickmen on April
the Eighteenth

The gap in the lacrosse schedule
caused by the cancellation of the
Oxford-Cambridge game has been
filled by definite arrangements to
Play the Onondaga Indians on
April 18. The Indians, an independent team from New York State,
have an unusually strong club, and
last year succeeded in tying Syracuse, leaders of the Northern Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association. One
of their players, according to current report, is fifty-six years old,
and his son substitutes for him.
The further statement of a campus
authority on athletics that his grandson is water boy seems uncalled for.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. MD., MARCH 6, 1925

It's Up To Students—Says Van Orman
Coach Ray Van Orman, athletic director of the university,
says that the success of the Spring Season Ticket Campaign
depends entirely on the undergraduates. When interviewed on
the prospects of the campaign which began yesterday Dr. Van
Orman said:
"It is entirely up to the undergrads. It is their game, their
sport, it is up to them to make it go across. It ought to be a
mutter of pride with any undergraduate to see that every possible sale will be made.
"Undergrads are selling something of their Own. The
same thing sold by an outsider would not go, across, but when
a man sells his own goods he knows their worth."

The official sale of 1925 spring
season tickets was inaugurated
yesterday when letters were sent
to fifteen hundred and eighty-five
alumni and three hundred and fifty
faculty members living in Baltimore and its vicinity. Every recipient of a letter will be visited
by a member of one of the 18 specially selected teams organized for
the purpose of selling the tickets.
This will be done during the
course of this week-end and during next week.

THE FLAG, BANNER AND
PENNANT SHOP
FARE SUMPTIOUSLY AT HOPKINS CLUB
"We aim to please" is the motto
of the Johns.Hopkins Club cafeteria. The management says that
the men get as much as they want
of first class quality food.
For the midday meal, the diners, chiefly young instructors,
usually have a roast, two vegetables, and dessert. These are supplemented very often, though, by
other delicacies left over from the
day before. This is particularly
true of desserts. Occasionally a
few extra pies will be baked, put
into the pantry, and added to the
following day's menu. Then some
sharp-eyed
professor, passing
through the pantry, will spy the
pie and make short work of it.
Desserts, 'however, are not the
only food from which the profs
can choose. The chef knows the
fancies and peculiarities of each
man's diet, and tries to give everyone just what he wants. For instance, one man may not like
roasts. Something else will then
be provided for him—cold meats.
or possibly a canned vegetable.
There is always something on
hand to fall back on. Then, if anything is left over from the day before, that is put on the table for
those who may prefer it to the
regular menu. The men enjoy
having a selection.
Dinner comes at six o'clock.
First is soup, often tomato soup.
Then follows the usual meal—

meat, vegetables, and once a week
fish.
Home-made pie is the favorite
dish. Mince pie, cherry pie, lemon
pie, apple, cocoanut pie. and every
other kind in the cook book are
consumed regularly.
There are about eight men Who
live at the club and eat all their
meals there. In addition to these,
twelve to fifteen usually eat breakfast and dinner there. More men
take their lunch at the Club, however, than any other meal. The
reason for this, of course, is that
many of the diners have their own
homes in other parts of the city,
and consequently have breakfast
and dinner with their families.
Wednesday is the biggest day ot
the week, when over forty eat at
the club. The other days average
about thirty-five each.
Though it was mentioned that
young instructors constitute the
majority of diners, this does not
mean that the older men do not
frequent the cafeteria. President
Goodnow, Dr. Bliss, Dr. Latane,
and a number of other older faculty members take meals there
more or less regularly.

HOPKINS LACROSSE MEN
TO MEET ONONDAGA
INDIANS
Red:nen from North Will Test Black
and Blue Stickmen on April
the Eighteenth

The gap in the lacrosse schedule
caused by the cancellation of the
Oxford-Cambridge game has been
filled by definite arrangements to
Play the Onondaga Indians on
April 18. The Indians, an independent team from New York State,
have an unusually strong club, and
last year succeeded in tying Syracuse, leaders of the Northern Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association. One
of their players, according to current report, is fifty-six years old,
and his son substitutes for him.
The further statement of a campus
authority on athletics that his grandson is water boy seems uncalled for.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE. MD., MARCH 6, 1925

It's Up To Students—Says Van Orman
Coach Ray Van Orman, athletic director of the university,
says that the success of the Spring Season Ticket Campaign
depends entirely on the undergraduates. When interviewed on
the prospects of the campaign which began yesterday Dr. Van
Orman said:
"It is entirely up to the undergrads. It is their game, their
sport, it is up to them to make it go across. It ought to be a
mutter of pride with any undergraduate to see that every possible sale will be made.
"Undergrads are selling something of their Own. The
same thing sold by an outsider would not go, across, but when
a man sells his own goods he knows their worth."

FARE SUMPTIOUSLY AT HOPKINS CLUB
"We aim to please" is the motto
of the Johns.Hopkins Club cafeteria. The management says that
the men get as much as they want
of first class quality food.
For the midday meal, the diners, chiefly young instructors,
usually have a roast, two vegetables, and dessert. These are supplemented very often, though, by
other delicacies left over from the
day before. This is particularly
true of desserts. Occasionally a
few extra pies will be baked, put
into the pantry, and added to the
following day's menu. Then some
sharp-eyed
professor, passing
through the pantry, will spy the
pie and make short work of it.
Desserts, 'however, are not the
only food from which the profs
can choose. The chef knows the
fancies and peculiarities of each
man's diet, and tries to give everyone just what he wants. For instance, one man may not like
roasts. Something else will then
be provided for him—cold meats.
or possibly a canned vegetable.
There is always something on
hand to fall back on. Then, if anything is left over from the day before, that is put on the table for
those who may prefer it to the
regular menu. The men enjoy
having a selection.
Dinner comes at six o'clock.
First is soup, often tomato soup.
Then follows the usual meal—

meat, vegetables, and once a week
fish.
Home-made pie is the favorite
dish. Mince pie, cherry pie, lemon
pie, apple, cocoanut pie. and every
other kind in the cook book are
consumed regularly.
There are about eight men Who
live at the club and eat all their
meals there. In addition to these,
twelve to fifteen usually eat breakfast and dinner there. More men
take their lunch at the Club, however, than any other meal. The
reason for this, of course, is that
many of the diners have their own
homes in other parts of the city,
and consequently have breakfast
and dinner with their families.
Wednesday is the biggest day ot
the week, when over forty eat at
the club. The other days average
about thirty-five each.
Though it was mentioned that
young instructors constitute the
majority of diners, this does not
mean that the older men do not
frequent the cafeteria. President
Goodnow, Dr. Bliss, Dr. Latane,
and a number of other older faculty members take meals there
more or less regularly.
